Title: Construction labourer
Overview: Construction labourers prepare building and civil engineering sites and carry out manual jobs once work starts.

EntryRouteSummary: You can get into this job through:a college course; an apprenticeship; applying directly

RelevantSubjects: You could start by taking a college course like:Level 1 Certificate in Construction Skills; Level 2 Certificate in Construction Operations
EntryRequirements: 2 or fewer GCSEs at grades 3 to 1 (D to G), or equivalent, for a level 1 course
2 or more GCSEs at grades 9 to 3 (A* to D), or equivalent, for a level 2 course

RelevantSubjects: You can do a groundworker or construction operations intermediate apprenticeship.
EntryRequirements: some GCSEs, usually including English and maths, or equivalent, for an intermediate apprenticeship

DirectApplication: You can apply directly for jobs. There are no set requirements, though it will be helpful if you've got on-site experience.

Registrations: you'll need a [Construction Skills Certification Scheme | https://www.cscs.uk.com] (CSCS) card or equivalent to train and work on a construction site
FurtherInformation: You can find out more about working in construction from [Go Construct | https://www.goconstruct.org/learn-about-construction/find-the-role-for-you/career-explorer/general-construction-operative/] and [House Building Careers | https://housebuildingcareers.org.uk/].

WhatItTakes.DigitalSkillsLevel: to be able to carry out basic tasks on a computer or hand-held device

Skills.Description: knowledge of building and construction
to be thorough and pay attention to detail
the ability to use, repair and maintain machines and tools
the ability to work well with your hands
the ability to work well with others
patience and the ability to remain calm in stressful situations
the ability to accept criticism and work well under pressure
knowledge of maths
the ability to use your initiative
customer service skills
knowledge of public safety and security
excellent verbal communication skills
physical skills like movement, coordination, dexterity and grace
physical fitness and endurance
active listening skills
thinking and reasoning skills
leadership skills
observation and recording skills
the ability to operate and control equipment
concentration skills

RelatedRestrictions: have a good level of fitness
OtherRequirements: To work with plant machinery like excavators or dumper trucks, you'll need to be 18 or over and have a driving licence.

WYDDayToDayTasks: Your day-to-day tasks may include:groundworking - marking out and digging trenches for foundations and drains; formworking - putting up panels that hold setting concrete in place; steel fixing - bending and fixing bars used to reinforce concrete structures; steel piling - joining steel sheets to form temporary retaining walls for excavations; concreting - laying concrete for foundations, floors and beams; road working - laying kerbs, paving and resurfacing
You'll also help tradespeople on site, like bricklayers, by keeping them supplied with materials and mortar.

WorkingEnvironment.Location: You could work on a construction site.
WorkingEnvironment.Environment: Your working environment may be at height, outdoors in all weathers and physically demanding.
WorkingEnvironment.Uniform: You may need to wear protective clothing.

CareerPathAndProgression: You could train on the job to become a qualified tradesperson or with experience, become a site supervisor, estimator or construction manager.
